comment: As in a Caro-Kann variation Black accepts that Pg7 is weak and must be defended this awkward way. Perhaps one of the more important details is that White needs to retreat Ne5 to avoid another minor piece exchange. The more exchanges the easier it will be for Black to complete his development and the harder it would be for White to generate an attack.

comment: The capture works after all. 38...Qxe6 allows 39. Qg7+ to win Rh8 and 38...Ke6 allows 39. Rd6+ which wins Qf6. This relentless attack wasn't so flashy as many, but it was very accurate and showed the pawns can't leave a king exposed without major consequences. In this case the defense was good, but the position was (apparently) irreparable. That the White pieces won this and the Adams-Anand games using this same (new to my knowledge) opening idea is notable. Anand didn't lose because of it, he misplayed a queen and pawn ending, but Ponomariov never quite recovered from the positional weaknesses around his king, created during the opening and early middle-game. Kasparov takes the lead in the tournament with only one round to go!
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake made by the player, as it points out that the rook cannot chase the queen without winning the pawn, which the commenter had already analyzed.

context: This is a game between Kasparov, Garri (as White) and Ponomariov, Ruslan (as Black). Last move played: White plays Rook takes on e6 with check
reformulated: The rook capture was strategic but not brilliant, as it allowed Black to play Qxe6, which then let White's queen win the rook on h8. Black's move Ke6 set up a winning position for the White rook on d6. The defense was solid, but the position was poor for Black due to the early positional issues. In the Adams-Anand games, White used a similar opening idea, but Anand lost not because of this, but due to a mistake in a queen and pawn endgame. Black's positional weaknesses were the result of the opening and early middle-game, and Kasparov won the tournament with one round remaining.
